text: The room is dark. A perfectly square mirror hangs crooked a wall. Suddenly, out of the darkness, the reflection of a man's  face comes into focus. He stares straight ahead, perhaps  studying his own unrecognizable reflection. It's quite cl this is a portrait of sickness; the man's pallor is gray, his eyes are confused. There is something most definitely wrong. Tentatively, the figure steps away from the mirror, leavi the frame empty and dark.
Like a ghost, the naked man (Harvey) stands over his bed  staring down at his sleeping wife (Joyce). In the eerie l he's almost translucent.
(faintly) Joyce... Joyce?
Joyce springs up, alarmed.
What's wrong, Harvey? What are you  doing up?
Harvey just stands there for a moment saying nothing.
What is it?
(delirious, out of  breath) Tell me the truth. Am I some guy who  writes about himself in a comic book?  Or am I just -- am I just a character  in that book?
Joyce rubs her eyes.
Harvey...
If I die, will 'dat character keep  goin'? Or will he just fade away...
Joyce just stares at him, unsure how to answer. Suddenly  Harvey collapses. Joyce leaps from the bed, nervous, hysterical. She gets d on the floor and shakes him.
Omigod, Harvey! Harvey, wake up!
His eyes remain closed, his expression far, far away.

A surreal kaleidoscope of black, white and red. Similar t the mirror scene above, the colors slowly come into focus revealing the chiseled features of a familiar face. But t time we see that it is not a real face, but rather a plas mask of the D.C. Comic hero -- SUPERMAN.

It glows eerily in the light of a porch lamp. A child's p glare through the eye holes... The camera pans from SUPERMAN to the masked face of anoth caped-crusader: BATMAN. Batman turns toward his loyal sid ROBIN, who clutches a plastic, trick-or-treat pumpkin. Next, we find THE GREEN LANTERN as he reaches up to ring doorbell. The camera finally rests on the last boy: an un KID wearing no costume at all. Looking irritated and remo from the rest of the group, the KID shoves his hands in t pockets of his shearling coat. He spits and rolls his eyes as a lady answers the door. The brick home is as working class as it gets. The lady a the door is a 1950's HOUSEWIFE.
(in unison) Trick or treat!!
Well, look at this! All the  superheroes on the porch! Ain't that  cute.
The Lady drops a candy apple in each boy's container.
(still yelling) We got Superman here, Batman, his  sidekick ROBIN, ohh, The Green Lantern  even...
She finally stops at the costumeless KID. He halfheartedl holds up a ratty, stained pillowcase.
And what about you young man?
What about what?
The other boys giggle. The kid flashes them a "kick yer a look.
Who are you supposed to be?
The kid shrugs.
I'm Harvey Pekar (pronounced "Pee  Car").
Harvey Pekar? That doesn't sound  like a super hero to me...
(mumbling) Pecker, Pecker...
I ain't no super hero, lady. I'm  just a kid from the neighborhood,  alright?
The Housewife stares at him, confused.
Ahh, forget this...
Frustrated, the kid throws his pillowcase down. He trudge off as the others watch in confusion.
Why is everybody so stoopid?
WE FOLLOW the schlumpy kid (aka HARVEY PEKAR) as he sulks down the street...

A grown-up version of HARVEY PEKAR (now mid-thirties) sto along the same Cleveland street. Unfortunately, 20 years  have made this rust belt neighborhood a bit rustier. The  "GROWN UP HARVEY" dons the same shearling coat, sports th same disheveled hair, and wears the same curmudgeonly  expression.
is not your typical super-hero stuff. Instead it features our man engaging in such daredevil fe as:
--Riding the city bus.
--Working as a file clerk at the Veteran's Hospital.
--Trying to wash dishes.
--Waiting on line at the supermarket.
--Buying used records from a garage sale table.
--Eating junk food at a greasy spoon.

Harvey fixes a rip in his coat with Elmer's Glue. (Note: Each "Cartoon Harvey" looks similar but unique... variation on a theme. This is because his cartoons are dr by different comic artists.) Intermittently, bold cartoon credits flash across the scr

head_text.speaker/title: FROM OFF THE STREETS OF CLEVELAND COMES...

text: Followed by the explosive title:
The high-energy music and upbeat titles -- in direct cont to the sulking image of Harvey -- continue through the  remainder of the credits.
We're now on HARVEY'S back as he continues his forlorn  journey. We move forward, past him, to peer over the hill the factories below.

Okay. We're throwing a lot at ya  here, so lemme step in an' help ya  catch up. This is the story about  comic books, an' a guy who made a  whole life outta them. You could  even say comics saved his life. This  guy here, he's our man, Harvey Pekar --  all grown up and goin' nowhere.  Although he's a pretty scholarly  cat, he never got much of a formal  education. For the most part, he's  lived in shit neighborhoods, held  shit jobs, and is now knee deep into  a second disastrous marriage. So if  yer lookin' for romance or escapism  or some fantasy figure to save the  day, guess what? Ya got the wrong  movie.

The REAL HARVEY PEKAR (not the actor who trudged through credits) sits behind a microphone, supplying the "voice o above. He clutches a movie script in his hand. The frame is spare, with a few well-chosen items to indic that he's in a recording session. Although he is significantly older than the man who portr him, the "Real Harvey" is every bit as much of a sad sack maybe even more. He is large and slightly threatening wit knitted brows and wild eyes. Yet there is something kind vulnerable about him -- a teddy bear who could kick your  ass. Off Camera, WE HEAR the voices of the male and femal directors (us -- BOB and SHARI) coaching the "Real Harvey through his voice over. Harvey's irritable and contrary,  saying that the whole Halloween incident never even happe "But I don't care man. I'm just doing this for the dough. We learn that Harvey is a reluctant participant in a film being made about his life. SUDDENLY, his third wife JOYCE BRABNER -- an intelligent  control freak obsessed with all things negative -- joins the conversation. Pushing back her huge glasses, she  reprimands Harvey like he is an infant: "Harvey you are  talking too loud, Harvey you are being difficult." Harvey just rolls his eyes. Joyce gets offended. It is clear the have had this argument a million times. As Joyce storms o Harvey explains that his wife is trying to take over the  movie. He laments that she is his third wife, and he has luck with women. "Man, chicks just don't dig me." That's he marries anyone who will have him. "And I marry them fa before they get to know the real me..."

head_text.subj: END HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE

text: HARVEY sits on a table in his T-shirt and underwear. A DO unwraps a tongue depressor. Harvey's voice is hoarse, raspy and barely audible. It so like it hurts for him to talk. Yet, he can't stop ranting

Doc, you gotta help me. My old lady's  dumping me 'cause I can't talk. She  says I'm a social embarrassment. Now  that she's got her PhD, she's some  hot shit academic star an' I'm nuthin'  but a file clerk with nothin' ta say  an' no voice ta say it. But me bein'  a file clerk was fine when I wrote  the damn check for her tuition --
Harvey, stop talking please, and  open wide.
He points the tongue depressor at Harvey's mouth but he j keeps on going.
I just don't get it... We were doin'  okay for a while. Then we took that  stupid belated honeymoon. I started  losin' my voice on the plane. Can  you believe that... On the plane,  doc?
Bad timing, I guess. Now please say  "Ah," Mr. Pekar.

"Ahhh." (without missing a  beat) "Ahhh" ruined the trip. I got crazy,  started to worry my voice would never  come back. I mean, my wife didn't  know me so long before we got hitched.  What if she totally forgets what I'm  like? Man, it's torture --
Shhh...
The Doctor shines a penlight into Harvey's mouth and look around.
Uh-huh.
He raises an eyebrow. Harvey catches this. Hypochondria  overtakes him.
(the penlight in his  mouth) What? Is it bad, doc?
The Doctor removes the penlight.
It's not good.
Harvey jumps off the table.
It's cancer? First I got marital  problems and now yer tellin' me I  got throat cancer? Omigod...

Harvey, calm down. It's not cancer.  You have a nodule on your vocal  chords. Probably from screaming and  yelling too much. And if you don't  stop talking and give it a rest,  you're gonna lose your voice  completely.
Relieved, Harvey calms down. He nods, agreeing to be good
Whew... Okay, okay. But fer how long?
A few months.
(loudly) Months!!
Suddenly Harvey's voice cracks under his effort to raise He sheepishly grabs his throat.
See? More of that and you'll do  permanent damage. Now go home, keep  your mouth shut, and hopefully we  won't have to operate.
Operate? Harvey gets nervous again. The Doctor throws him his clothing.

A silent sequence. A dejected HARVEY walks home alone alo an empty lot. Day-old dirty snow clings to the ground. He wanders through a down-in-the-heels neighborhood, pass run-down stores and ramshackle apartments.

Harvey approaches TOBY -- a dumpy 20-something going on 6 something in ridiculous, mismatched polyester clothing. H is odd, awkward and talks with a monotone, robotic voice. short, he is a super dork.
Hi Harvey. You weren't in work today.  Are you okay, Harvey?
Harvey barely looks up. He nods his head "yes" and keeps  walking.
(yelling after him) I'm heading downtown to the White  Castle. Wanna come, Harvey?
Harvey leaves Toby behind and turns the corner.
Two WOMEN argue loudly over a payphone.
(in Spanish) I already told you, I'm waiting for  a call!
Oh yeah? Since when is this your  private office?!
Since you can kiss my ass.
Harvey stops in his tracks and stares at them, jealous of their ability to speak. CLOSE UP: SPANISH WOMAN #1's MOUTH
(to himself) Look at 'em yakkin'. How do they do  it?
Out of the corner of her eye, WOMAN #2 notices Harvey  eavesdropping.
(yelling at Harvey) Ay, what are you looking at? Maricone!
Startled, Harvey moves on.
He passes a group of KIDS playing in the snow. They screa yell and laugh with abandon.
(shaking his head) They all make it seem so easy.
Then, BAM! Harvey is awakened from his reverie by a snowb The kids laugh loudly. He wipes away the snow and walks o A VOICE OVER interrupts the scene.

Here's our man walking home from the  doctor's. He's got the weight of the  world on him. And fer what, really?  'Cause his throat's a little screwy?  Man, people in India are starvin' to  death every day. His problems are  nothin'.
Totally dejected, HARVEY crosses over train tracks on his way home.
Still, he can't help feelin' paranoid,  like some supernatural force is  conspiring against him to rob him of  his voice.
Harvey sulks up the steps of his brick low-rise apartment building. He passes an ELDERLY NEIGHBOR coming down the w with her shopping cart. Harvey unlocks the door.
Maybe his old lady will go easy on  him today, when she sees how upset  he is.

Harvey's second wife LANA -- a hippyish chic with long ha and a bad attitude -- pulls books off a shelf and selecti throws them onto the floor or packs them into a milk crat An overstuffed suitcase sits beside her. She's obviously  leaving him. HARVEY enters the room.
(whispering) Ay... What is this?
Harvey's voice breaks up.
Exactly what it looks like.
(loud) Whattya mean!! You mean yer dumpin'  me?! Fer what? (his voice really  rips) Ah, shit!
That last yell did it. Harvey grabs throat in pain, torn  between his throat discomfort and trying to stop his wife from leaving.
Look, your plebeian lifestyle isn't  working for me anymore. Cleveland's  not working for me anymore. I gotta  get out of here before I kill myself.
But --
She gathers her bags and heads for the door. Harvey trail her, trying to reason. He opens his mouth, but nothing comes out.
(mouthing, just a  wheeze) Please! Wait, honey... Just listen  to what I got to say...

She turns and stares at him. Harvey tries to say somethin But now nothing at all comes out of his mouth. Only wheez air. He tries again. No sound at all. Finally LANA gives up, turns back towards the door and le
At his cubicle in the file room, Harvey fills a cart with files. He's physically at work, but mentally in a daze.

Here's our man -- yeah alright, here's  me -- or the guy playin' me, anyway,  though he don't look nothin' like  me, but whatever. So it's a few months  later an' I'm workin' my flunky,  file-clerk gig at the V.A. Hospital.  My voice still ain't back yet. Things  seem like they can't get any worse...
A nurse pops her head in. Harvey hands her a file.
Thank you, Harvey dear.
He doesn't hear her, still stewing about LANA. He shoves last files in the cart and pushes it away.
(to himself) Plebeian... where the hell did she  get that shit?
We see rows and rows of endless files... Still in a daze, Harvey removes the files from the cart a puts them on the shelves.
Avoid the reeking herd! Shun the  polluted flock! Live like that stoic  bird, The eagle of the rock!
Harvey turns around. Mr. Boats -- a portly, African-Ameri maintenance worker wearing a bow-tie -- steps into Harvey row. He has a tool box.
Huh? Oh. Hiya, Mr. Boats.
Harvey resumes shelving.
You know what that means, son?
Yeah. It's from an Elinor Hoyt Wylie  poem. It means stay away from the  crowds of common ordinary people an'  do yer own thing.
Mr. Boats laughs.
Nope, it means don't compromise  yourself for women. Ain't gonna do  you no good! Get away from 'em as  soon as you can!
Well I ain't got no woman now. So  I'm living like the stoic bird, man.
The only way to live, son.
Somehow this doesn't make Harvey feel any better about hi life.

Harvey carries an armful of files. Mr. Boats still trails him, lugging his tool box. Suddenly, Mr. Boats points out a young African-American F CLERK wearing a pair of big headphones on his afro. He mo as if he's listening to music.
Look at that fool over there. What's  he wearing?
Huh? That's an A.M.-F.M. radio he's  listening to... They got 'em fixed  up now like a pair of earmuffs.
(inappropriately  angered) MMPH! Isn't that somethin! People  have gone crazy. They'll buy any  kinda junk! Probably listening to  that loud rock stuff. Junk, junk,  it's all junk!
Well, I don't know. Rock music's got  some good qualities. I mean it ain't  jazz or nothin'.
Mr. Boats looks at him like he's crazy.
Say, when you gonna bring me in some  good records? Some Nat "King" Cole  with Strings...
I don't got any of that, Mr. Boats...
Mr. Boats stops and yells down the hall at Harvey.
Yeah, you got it... You're keepin'  it at home, though! You won't turn  loose the good stuff... You just  sell the junk!
Harvey shakes his head as Mr. Boats finishes his diatribe Mr. Boats turns into a room.
(singing) Mona Lisa, Mona Lisa. Men have named  you.

Harvey sits on outdoor furniture. A few props are feature in the frame indicating a garage-sale-like setting (inclu a record player). Directly in front of Harvey are boxes o used records. HARVEY shows us his prodigious record collection. Thousan of LP's -- rare jazz, blues, fusion, klezmer, etc. -- are piled in floor-to-ceiling bookcases. He tells us about his love of jazz and how he started wri jazz reviews and music articles. He finds the first recor that he reviewed and puts it on his turntable. As the mus plays... Harvey talks about how he started buying and selling reco This leads into how he first met ROBERT CRUMB.
HARVEY (a little more hair but the exact same style) and bunch of his BUDDIES sift through old records at a junk s

In the early sixties I was with some  buddies at a junk sale looking for  some choice sides when I met this  shy, retiring cat from Philadelphia  named Bob Crumb. You know the guy;  Fritz the Cat, Mr. Natural an' all --  they made a movie about him, too.
One of Harvey's pals -- MARTY -- pulls a record out of a  box.
C'mon, Harv. You dig Jay McShann.  You gonna buy that or what?
Harvey jumps up from his search to check out the LP.
I don't know, Marty. It's got a  lamination crack in it... (checking out the  price) A quarter. Maybe I can get him down.
You are one cheap bastard Harvey.
Yeah, I know I'm tight, man, but I  live on a government wage.
A skinny guy with a big nose, glasses and a ratty trench  coat taps Harvey on the shoulder. He is soft-spoken, a bi shy and very odd -- a young ROBERT CRUMB.
You collect Jay McShann, man?
Yeah, man. How 'bout you?
Yeah but most of my records are back  in Philly.
A greaser-type guy in a leather jacket, PAHLS, joins them
Harv, meet my buddy Bob Crumb. He  just moved to town. He's an artist  at American Greeting Card Company.
That's cool.
You should see his comics, Harv.  They are outta sight.
(interested) Yeah? I'm into comics myself.
A disheveled mess that gives new meaning to the term bach pad. Records and books are strewn everywhere.
So Crumb showed me this comic book  novel he was working on -- THE BIG  YUM YUM BOOK. I'd never seen anything  like it.

HARVEY marches back and forth holding Crumb's illustrated comic novel. CRUMB sits on the floor nursing a beer and  sorting through vintage comic books. Harvey's bursting wi so much enthusiasm, it's almost aggressive.
It's terrific, man! I really dig  your work.
Crumb ignores Harvey's praise.
(holding up a vintage  comic) This PETER WHEAT book is by Walt  Kelly... It's pretty rare.
Yeah? Can I get good bread for it?
Nah! Not yet.
Harvey flops down in an overstuffed chair. Stuffing flies out. He sips his beer.
Listen man, let's get back to your  book. What are you gonna do with it?
(looking up) I hadn't thought about it. It's just  an exercise.
Harvey flips through the book.
It's more than an exercise. It's  breaking ground, man. There's some  wild shit in here.
Crumb is immune to Harvey's enthusiasm.
You're spitting on me, Harvey.
CRUMB lies on the couch sketching while HARVEY reads more THE YUM YUM BOOK. A scratchy jazz record plays.
Crumb and I hung out a lot back then.  We had records and comics in common.
We see Crumb is actually sketching Harvey, slumped in a c reading a book. Crumb makes Harvey look like a smelly, sw madman with ratty clothing. Crumb holds the sketch of Harvey up to show him.
(laughing) Check it out, man. Pretty scary.
Harvey glances up at his portrait, completely unselfconsc
Yeah, ya don't know the half of it.
Harvey goes back to reading. Crumb back to sketching.

Eventually people got hip to Crumb's  art work and he started hangin' out  with a Bohemian crowd. After a while,  he got sick of greeting cards and  moved away to San Francisco where he  got the whole underground comic scene  off the ground.
Crumb slowly evaporates from the room, leaving Harvey tot alone.
He'd come back ta Cleveland every  few years, an' people'd treat him  like a celebrity.
The record spins and spins...

ANOTHER R. CRUMB DRAWING OF HARVEY (Now circa 1975) On a sketch pad we see a deranged, tormented Harvey sitti alone on a park bench. He pulls at his hair, and looks as though he may murder the next person who walks by.
As the pencil adds shading to Harvey's face, WE HEAR:

Once he came to visit when I was  really feelin' bad. It was right  around the time of my throat  operation, an' right after my second  wife left me. At first it was pretty  weird. I mean, here my life was  falling apart an' everything was  going great for him. I was on my  second divorce an' he was a big hit  with the chicks. I was a nothin'  file clerk and he was this famous  cartoonist.
HARVEY and R. CRUMB sit on a park bench together by a bus stop. A distraught Harvey whines while Crumb just sketche Harvey's voice is still raspy.

I dunno, man. On the one hand most  women gettin' graduate degrees  wouldn't give a guy like me the time  a' day. An' she married me an'  everything, so I gotta give her some  kinda credit. But then she got so  mean to me in the end. An' it ain't  like I tried t'keep her captive or  anything like that, y'know?
Crumb may or may not be listening to Harvey. It's hard to tell.

An' then on top of it I lost my voice  for three months. I still sound like  shit, but before I had nothin'. Man,  talk about hell. I started forgettin'  what I sound like, y'know? So I  started writin' stuff down -- stories  an' things, my points a' view, ideas.  I even published a couple jazz record  reviews. I guess that ended up bein'  a good thing.
Uh-huh.

But don't think I buy into this  "growth" crap. Everybody talks about  how bad experiences can cause ya  t'grow, an' all that cliched stuff.  I've had enough bad experiences and  growth to last me plenty. (a beat) Right now, I'd be glad to trade some  growth for happiness.
For a moment, they both just sit there saying nothing to  each other, each man in his own private universe. Finally Harvey looks over to Crumb.
So how long are ya stayin' in  Cleveland?
Crumb never looks up from his picture.
I dunno, man. I gotta go visit this  chick in New York. And I'm really  busy with the comic book stuff. It's  good bread and all man but I'm getting  fed up with the whole scene.
What are ya talkin' about? Yer makin'  a good living doin' yer art? Sheesh.  How many guys get that lucky in their  life, huh?
Yeah, I dunno.
Ya know man, people are startin' to  know the name "Crumb." When you croak  you're gonna leave something behind.
Yeah, my ashes and some crappy  doodles. It's not like I'm Blind  Lemon Jefferson or Big Mama Thornton.
C'mon, man. It sure beats workin' a  gig like mine -- being a nobody flunky  and sellin' records on the side for  a buck.
Yeah, well that's true...
Harvey nods in agreement, mulling this over. He's not at offended.

A hand reaches into the frame and opens the drawer. By rote, HARVEY fumbles with a large stack of "expired  patient" files. He places each into the appropriate  alphabetical "deceased" drawer. Attempting to grab another batch, Harvey accidentally kno the entire pile onto the floor.
Damn it!

He crouches down to survey the mess -- a collage of "expi lives" laid out before his eyes. We move past dozens of anonymous names -- William Anderso Louis Collins, Mark D'Amico, Tyrone Moore, Franklin Ray,  etc... Each file has a red "Deceased" stamp. Depressed, HARVEY is transfixed by the files surrounding on the floor. Suddenly he stops and picks one up. ANGLE ON FOLDER: It is marked, "CHARLIE MARSHALL." He opens the folder and reads the stats... Born: 1920 in Cleveland Died: 1920 in Cleveland Occupatio Clerk ANGLE ON HARVEY: He swallows hard as he reads about Charl small, invisible and now vanished life... He tosses the f back onto the pile.

HARVEY sits at a table with a pen in hand and a blank she of paper in front of him. Nothing seems to come to him. He flips through a pile of comic books -- everything from D.C. Comic Super Heroes to underground works such as Crum Mr. Natural and Zap Comix. No inspiration. Harvey throws  them down in frustration.
I'm starvin'.
HARVEY pushes a cart through the cramped aisles of a crow supermarket. He pulls a few cans of Beef-A-Roni off the s and heads off to pay. Reaching the check-out area, he  evaluates the situation.
There are three lines to choose from. Two of the counters have long waits. The third is much shorter but there is a OLD JEWISH LADY next in line.

head_text.subj: SUDDENLY, THE SCREEN SPLITS IN TWO

text: The LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME remains Harvey at the supermar deliberating over the check-out lines. However, the RIGHT SIDE OF THE FRAME now contains a CRUMB

appears over CARTOON HARVEY'S head revealing his thoughts It reads: "Pickin' the right check-out line is an art...  There's a lot of things you gotta consider." ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME... Harvey decides to get be the Old Lady. MEANWHILE ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE OF THE FRAME... Cartoon  Harvey stands behind the Old Lady. A new BUBBLE reads: "It may be the shortest line but I am takin' a chance 'cause she's an Old Jewish Lady." BACK TO THE LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME... The CASHIER rings u the Old Lady's purchases -- a few kitchen glasses.

(Yiddish Accent) Listen, goily, dese glasses are six  for $2.00 because I couldn't carry  twelf... But I vanted twelf so today  I'm buying six more... But you should  only charge me $1.50 for dem... It's  ok, you can esk de meneger.
Harvey rolls his eyes and stamps his foot impatiently. He knows he's in trouble now.
(yelling) Frank! I need a price check.

head_text.subj: SUDDENLY, THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE SCREEN BECOMES FULLY

text: ANIMATED... Instead of still comic panels with balloons, Cartoon Harvey now rants directly into the camera.
Man, Old Jewish Ladies will argue  forever with a cashier about anything.  Get behind them in a line an' yer  gonna wait forever!
The Human Harvey seems oblivious to his cartoon replica. impatiently leans on his cart, waiting and seething.
I mean, I'm a yid myself, an' the  women in my family are like that...  But I never got used to it... I may  be cheap, but I got limits!
ON THE LEFT HAND SIDE OF THE SCREEN... The MANAGER finall arrives. The Old Lady haggles with him, too.
Please. Let me 'splain von more time.
MEANWHILE ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE... The Cartoon Harvey tu to address the Human Harvey, who actually looks him in th eyes. It now seems Human Harvey can actually hear his car alter ego.

Wake up! You're whole life's gettin'  eaten away by this kinda crap! What  kind of existence is this? Is this  all a workin' stiff like you can  expect? Ya gonna suffer in silence  fer the rest a' yer life?! Or ya  gonna make a mark. Huh? Huh?

head_text.subj: IN AN INSTANT, THE CARTOON HARVEY DISAPPEARS AND THE LIVE
ACTION SCENE TAKES OVER THE WHOLE FRAME.

text: Suddenly motivated by an odd notion, Harvey abandons his  grocery cart and runs out of the supermarket.
Bursting with ideas, Harvey (wearing his undershirt and  boxers) starts story-boarding his first comic with stick  figures.

A bleary-eyed HARVEY, still clad in an undershirt and box dozes off over a bowl of Corn Flakes. On the table next t some spilled milk are a stack of papers covered with  scribbling. He clearly has been slaving over this work al night.

At the top is a quickly scribbled title, "Standing Behind Old Jewish Ladies In Supermarket Lines." These are ad hoc versions of a comic book. The pages are divided like a ti tack-toe board. Each square is filled with crude stick fi drawings and lots of writing. An alarm clock goes off. Harvey's eyes fly open.
Shit. Work.
Harvey yawns, then notices the pile of papers. He peruses them, proud of his work. He gets up and looks out the win

It is yet another grey day in Cleveland. The neighborhood run-down. Garbage is strewn everywhere. The following scene unfolds through the window: Two UNSIGHTLY WORKERS lug an old, smelly mattress from a  garage towards the garbage cans on the curb. Their  conversation is distant, but entirely audible.
So how smart is she?
I dunno. I guess she's about average.
Average? Hey, man. Average is dumb!
They drop the mattress in place. With the window framing  these guys, the scene FREEZES, looking just like a comic  book panel.
Harvey turns around from the scene and ponders it. He mov back towards his pile of stick-figure drawings.
Harvey scribbles the words "AMERICAN SPLENDOR" at the top the page.

The following scene is shot through the restaurant window We see reflections of people walking by. A tense HARVEY starts at CRUMB as he eats a burger and re Harvey's mock-ups. Harvey doesn't touch his burger deluxe and nervously talks in his laryngitis-afflicted voice.
See, ever since I read your stuff,  man I've been thinking I could write  comic book stories that were different  from anything being done.
(munching on a fry) Uh-huh.

I'm thinkin', the guys who do animal  comics and super-hero stuff are really  limited 'cause they gotta try to  appeal to kids. And underground comics  like yours have been really subversive  or opened things up politically. But  there is still plenty more ta be  done with 'em, too, y'know?
Pass me the ketchup?

I mean with pictures and words, it  could be more of an art form. Like  those French movies are. Or De Sica  over in Italy, y'know?... So I tried  writin' some things about real life.  Stuff the everyman's gotta deal with.
Crumb finally looks up from Harvey's work.
These are about you.
Er, yeah...
You turned yourself into a comic  hero?
Sorta, yeah. But no idealized shit.  No phony bullshit. The real thing,  y'know? Ordinary life is pretty  complex stuff.
Crumb reads more. Harvey waits anxiously. Finally Crumb s to chuckle.
These are really good, Harv.
(insecure) Really? Ya think so?
Crumb shuffles through more.
Yeah. This is great stuff, man. I  dig it. Can I take them home and  illustrate them?
Harvey is practically bursting.
Wow!!
Harvey's voice breaks like a kid in puberty. He clears hi throat. And something miraculous happens... When Harvey opens his mouth to speak his LARYNGITIS IS GO
You'd do that for me, man? That'd be  great! I can't draw a straight line!
Hey, what's up with your voice, Harv?  All of a sudden it sounds fine.
(thrilled) I don't know, man! I guess you cured  me!
HARVEY bounds towards the snack room where a group of hos workers and patients hang out. He bangs on the window to their attention. When they look up, Harvey waves a comic  book in the air.

head_text.subj: A GLOSSY, FULL-COLOR COMIC BOOK FEATURING THE TWO MATTRES

text: GUYS: Scrawled across the top in big red letters reads,  "AMERICAN SPLENDOR. Vol. #1" A man's finger points to the words, "All Stories by Harvey Pekar. Art by R. Crumb." Th comic book sits atop a table in the dreary snack room. A crowd of HOSPITAL WORKERS, PATIENTS, DOCTORS, MAINTENAN WORKERS, etc. (under ten total) gather around a proud HAR who shows off his work. For the first time, he seems almo happy.
(beaming) See that? All stories by yours truly.
A WWII VET PATIENT with a portable IV cranes to get a gli
Hot off the presses, huh? We got a  regular Hemingway here.
No way, Jack, I don't go in for that  macho crap.
DOCTOR #3 chimes in.
I didn't know you could draw, Pekar.
Nah! I don't draw. I just write the  stories. A buddy of mine and some of  his friends do the art work.
TOBY, the supernerd from the bus stop, grabs the comic bo off the table and peruses it.
Harvey, am I in here? You promised I  would be in here.
Yeah! Yeah! You're in there, alright?  Jeez, Toby.
SUDDENLY, MR. BOATS -- Harvey's philosophical co-worker - pushes his way thorough the crowd. He snatches the comic of Toby's hand.
Let me see this.
Mr. Boats, it's not polite to grab  things. Next time --
Son, you done good. Ya know, I was  up in Toronto a few weeks back an' I  saw the Red Chinese Ballet...
As Mr. Boats talks, the crowd starts to disperse.
Now that was beautiful. The way those  people were dancing together. Those  Chinese work hard. I tell ya, they  work hard -- Where is everybody goin'?
Mr. Boats hands the comic book back to Harvey and turns o his heels. Through the window he notices TWO VETS IN  WHEELCHAIRS moving down the hall.
Where these sickly men rushin' off  to? They ain't goin' nowhere for  now. Maybe not for a long time. But  damn if they ain't in a rush to get  there.
Harvey stands there, his moment of glory passed. But it's okay. He flips through his comic and smiles.
A motley group of GUYS hang out on a street corner in fro of the Association of Polish Women. HARVEY heads towards  them.
Hey look guys, here comes Captain  America.
Harvey rolls his eyes.
(yelling out) You gonna hang with the boys now  that yer a comic book star?
Harvey turns red. He's embarrassed but part of him loves attention.
Cut it out. Man, I ain't nothin' yet  compared to Bob Crumb.
Ah, listen to him. One lousy comic  book and he wants to be Crumb.
The GUYS laugh.
A SILENT GUY crouches by the wall, reading his CLEVELAND  BROWNS trading cards.
Hey Harvey, if ya wanna make comics  for adults, ya oughtta put some dirty  stuff in it.
Yeah, you can write about Marty's  sex life.
Harvey hangs with the guys but he doesn't engage. He seem to be observing them more than interacting with them.
Right Marty? I heard ya went out  with Bonnie yesterday.
Yeah. Howdja do? Wudja git offa her?
Ah, lousy. All's I got wuz armaround.
The guys all stare at him for a moment. Then they crack u

head_text.subj: OF THE ABOVE SCENE GRACES THE COVER.

text: A MARTY LOOK-ALIKE is bombarded with questions about his  date with Bonnie. He complains that all he got was "arm- around." The REAL HARVEY holds the above comic book in hi hand. The stage is set with a few items that indicate a c book store. HARVEY talks about a couple of "American Sple issues and how they impacted his life -- recognition as a writer, etc. He gives his philosophy about the comic book etc. A MONTAGE OF AMERICAN SPLENDOR COVERS (ISSUE #3, #4, #5, #6, ETC.) THEY INDICATE A PASSAGE OF TIME...
HARVEY sits alone in his cubicle. He doodles stick figure on a pad -- some ideas for a new comic. His posture's  miserable. He rubs his temples like he's in anguish.

Here's our man eight comics later, a  brand new decade, same old bullshit.  Yeah sure, he gets lots of recognition  for his writin' now. Sure his comics  are praised by all the important  media types tellin' people what to  think. But so what?  It's not like  he makes a livin' at it like Bob  Crumb. He can't go an' quit his day  job or nothin'.

Several shots of Harvey just thinking, scratching his fac with a pencil, tapping his foot nervously. Each shot is separated by a second or two of black (an ho to Harvey's wordless panels). Finally, he goes back to  writing.
Who am I kiddin'. Truth is I'd be  lost without my work routine.
Alone in bed, Harvey wakes up in a cold sweat from a  nightmare. He looks horrified, short of breath.
(calming himself down) I got a job... I got a job...
HARVEY scratches his head.
Harvey writes "I got a job" in a balloon over the stick  figure's head.

So -- to stave off desperation and  feelings of uselessness -- I resigned  myself to a menial existence. But  hey, maybe the guy who's had a happy  life feels worse just before he dies  than th' guy who had a sad one. Or,  maybe not. I dunno. Maybe I just  needed a woman.
Toby comes in, decked out in plaid and stripes. He has an empty messenger bag.
Hi, Harvey. Do you want these gourmet  jelly beans? I gave up sweets for  lent.
Harvey turns around. He seems down, depressed.
Huh? Sure, I'll take 'em.
Toby watches Harvey eat a few.
Hey, watermelon. That's pretty good.
I recommend the pina coladas. They  are excellent and very authentic  tasting.
Toby heads down a file row and proceeds to take a few off the shelves, stuffing his bag. Harvey gets up and comes a him.
Hey Toby, can you eat lentils during  lent?
Sure. I don't see why not. You can't  eat meat on certain days, but lentils  should be acceptable anytime.
Ya think there's any connection  between lentils and lent?
I don't think so but I'll ask Sister  Mary Fred at church on Sunday.
Sister Mary Fred, huh? Is she cute?  Sounds kinda mannish but who am I to  be picky.
Harvey, you're funny. She's a nun.
So what? Maybe she became a nun  because she couldn't get a guy.
Harvey, she became a nun because she  had a higher calling.
Higher calling. That is such a crock  of shit. I don't know why you waste  your time prayin' anyway.
Well, Harvey, I like the ritual. And  I'm a very spiritual person. You  know, you should try believing in  something bigger than yourself. It  might cheer you up.
Toby turns on his heels and walks off.
(calling after him) What? Do I seem depressed, Toby?
Toby doesn't respond. Harvey shrugs and digs deep into the jelly bean bag. He p out a fistful.
Jellybeans in every imaginable color. Harvey fingers a fe and then picks a blue one.
Cut!
A few items from the previous scene are present on the so stage indicating that it's a set of AMERICAN SPLENDOR -- Movie. THE ACTOR HARVEY stands alone, his hand filled with Jelly beans.
Okay, that was great. The bakery  scene is next...

ACTOR HARVEY steps out of the frame, revealing a craft se table behind him. At the table, the REAL HARVEY and the R TOBY load up on donuts. The two discuss the food on the s Ironically, the Real Toby is actually more extreme than t Actor who plays him -- even more robotic, and completely  incapable of eye-contact. The REAL TOBY discusses the finer points of nerdom and  evaluates the Actor's nerd quotient. The Real Harvey expl to Actor Toby that nothing -- not even gourmet jelly bean would have cheered him up at that point in his life. He was too lonely and depressed.

head_text.subj: END HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE

text: Light pours through the curtained window. Naked and disheveled, HARVEY tosses and turns in bed.
My loneliness was unbearable, man.  Weekends were the worst. Sometimes  in my sleep, I'd feel a body next to  me like an amputee feels a phantom  limb.
Extreme wide shot: a city-street overpass spans across th entire frame. The lone figure of Harvey sulks there in th middle, watching traffic pass below.
Sure my comics were bringin' me  notoriety, but my personal life was  in shambles. I thought a little  attention would make me feel better.  It only made me feel worse.

It is a beautiful, sunny day. The trees are in bloom. There's the first scent of spring in the air. Kids play i the street. Music pours out of passing cars. Everyone see to have a smile on his or her face except HARVEY. He walk on the shadowy side of the street.
Establishing shot of HARVEY trudging into the bakery.
A couple of WOMEN order bread and cookies from TWO COUNTE GIRLS. HARVEY surveys the donuts.
(yelling to Harvey) Next!
(to the Counter Girl) Yeah! I'll have two crullers, a jelly  donut with powdered sugar... And you  got any "day old bread"?
A woman with attractive Irish looks brushes past Harvey o her way to the door. This is ALICE QUINN, roughly Harvey' age but there is a tired, weary look in her eyes.
Hey, you're Harvey Pekar.
Half in a daze, Harvey stares at the chick.
Yeah...
Alice Quinn. From school.
Harvey studies her face. Suddenly, it clicks.
Oh yeah. College. We had a couple  lit classes together.
Harvey pays and receives his items. They step back toward the door.
What happened to you? You just  disappeared after one semester.
Harvey scratches his armpit.

I know, man. I got good grades and  all but there was this required math  class. I can't do math, an' that  required class hangin' over my head  made me crazy. Eventually the pressure  got to be too much.
Well, you're doing okay anyway. I  heard all about your jazz reviews  and your comics.
This perks Harvey up.
Ya did?
Sure, you're famous. Meanwhile I got  my degree but I'm just a plain old  wife and mother.
Harvey stares at her wedding ring. His face drops.

Yeah. I'm not doing as great as ya  think. My second wife divorced me  and I work at a dead end job as a  file clerk. Sometimes I hang out  with the guys on the corner but most  of the time I just stay home by myself  and read.
Alice laughs.
You're luckier than you think. My  husband and kids make it impossible  for me to cuddle up with a good book.
HARVEY and ALICE continue their conversation as they stro towards her car.
I'm reading this book by Dreiser now --  JENNIE GERHARDT.
That's one of my favorites.
I hope it don't end like so many a'  those naturalist novels... With  someone getting crushed ta earth by  forces he can't control.
Alice smiles.
I think you'll be pleasantly  surprised. It's certainly not a  Hollywood happy ending, but it's  pretty truthful. Which is rare these  days...
This hits home with Harvey. He can't believe he's made su a connection with this woman. Alice stops in front of a beat-up station wagon.
This is me.
Nice car. I don't have one yet.
Can I give ya a lift somewhere?
Nah. It's a nice day. I'll just walk.
Harvey looks down, a little sad.
Well, we should have you over sometime  for dinner.

Sure, I'd be glad t'come. But if you  really wanna do me a favor, introduce  me to some a' your single girlfriends.  I bet they're all smart like you.  I'm no catch, though, so I'll take  anything you can get me.
Alice pecks Harvey on the cheek.
I'll work on it.
She gets into the car.
Nice seeing ya Harvey.
Harvey watches as she drives off.
When I got home, I finished reading  JENNIE GERHARDT. It was real good,  way better than I expected. That  Alice wuz right.
The room is moody, dark and lonely. The shadowy figure of Harvey sits on the floor devouring JENNIE GERHARDT.
Sure Lester -- the main character --  croaks in the end, but at least he's  old and dies a natural dignified  death.
THE CAMERA TRAVELS AROUND THE ROOM TO FIND: Harvey again, now silhouetted in the door frame, still clutching the bo and obsessed by his thoughts.
I was more alone that weekend than  any. All I did was think about JENNIE  GERHARDT an' Alice Quinn an' all the  decades of people I have known.
THE CAMERA TRAVELS AGAIN TO FIND Harvey sitting on a chai in the corner of his room. His head is bowed. His shoulde slump over, as if he's struggling with something weighty.
The more I thought, the more I felt  like cryin'; Life seemed so sweet  an' so sad an' so hard t'let go of  in the end.

THE CAMERA TRAVELS A FINAL TIME TO FIND: Harvey sprawled  across his couch. But he's not asleep; he's still obsessi The book lies on his chest like a lover. CLOSE UP of Harvey's troubled face. Beneath the pain, we hope and determination.
But hey, man. Every day's a brand  new deal, right? Just keep on workin'  and sump'n's bound ta turn up.
An urban comic book shop on a dicey but bohemian street. title over picture reads, "MEANWHILE, IN DELAWARE."
JOYCE BRABNER, a depressive nudge with a perpetually pept expression frantically searches the store for something. partner, a granola type named RAND, finishes unloading a  stack on the shelf.
What happened to the new American  Splendor?
We sold 'em, babe.
All of them?
Yep.
(accusatory) Damn it! I put one aside for myself,  next to the register. I didn't even  get a chance to read it.
Whoa, sorry, Joyce. I didn't know  you were such a Splendor fan. Next  time take it home.
Joyce leans against the counter. She pushes up her glasse and looks really upset.
Maybe I'll call the publisher. But  they take so damn long. Shit! Why  does everything in my life have to  be such a complicated disaster...
Joyce starts slamming things around the store. Finally Ra grabs his stuff.
Okay, I'm gonna hustle before the  vibe in here gets any worse.
Rand leaves. Joyce barely notices, still brewing.
The mess in this room rivals Harvey's. A few cats add to clutter. Joyce lies on her disheveled bed and writes a le
Greetings from the second smallest  state in the union, an endless  plastics and nylon plantation  controlled by giant chemical  corporations.
HARVEY takes his mail out of the box. He finds an oddly  decorated envelope.
To make matters more dismal, there  are no decent comic book stores in  my town, which is why my partner and  I opened one ourselves.
HARVEY finishes reading the letter sitting on the toilet. cat runs around him.

Despite our steadily faltering  business, my partner managed to sell  the last copy of American Splendor  #8 out from under me. I'm a big fan  and I hate to wait for a new order.  Is there any way I can get it from  you direct? Sincerely, Joyce Brabner.
Harvey scratches his head. He mutters to himself.
...man, she's got good lookin'  handwritin'...
We see Harvey in his bed writing.
Dear Joyce, Thanks for the letter.  Whattya do besides sellin' comics?
We see Joyce standing in front of a GROUP OF PRISONERS.
I'm a sometime activist and I teach  writing to prisoners. I try to help  them build an interior life and make  art out of their monotonous,  suffocating routine.

head_text.subj: THE SCREEN GIVES WAY TO ANOTHER FRAME

text: Harvey scribbles a letter while riding on the bus.
Sounds familiar. So you married or  what?
Joyce empties her can of cat food in a plate and slides i towards her kitty.
I'm divorced, thank god.
Now we see Harvey (full screen) in bed in his underwear  talking on the PHONE. He's clipping his toe nails.
Look, I think you an' I got a lot in  common. How am I gonna get you to  come visit me in Cleveland?
Cleveland? You think that's a good  idea?
It's a great idea. You should meet  me, 'cause I'm a great guy. Despite  the way my comics read, I got a lot  of redeeming characteristics.
CLIP! He clips off a big one.
Joyce sits on her equally disheveled bed dunking a tea ba Her hair is wet from a shower.
I don't know. Where would I stay?
With me. Don't worry, I'm not gonna  put no moves on you or anything.
I'm not worried about that... (fumbling with a tea  cup) Hold on, I just spilled chamomile  tea all over my bathrobe.
So what are ya worried about then?
Joyce sighs and lies down. A variety of AMERICAN SPLENDOR are across her bed. Different interpretations of Harvey s up at her.

(sipping) Well, the way all those different  artists draw you, I don't quite know  what to expect. I mean sometimes you  look like a younger Brando, but then  the way Crumb draws you -- like a  hairy ape with all those stinky,  wavy lines radiating off your body --  it's kind of scary.
Those are motion lines. I'm an active  guy. Anyway, just come out here an'  I'll try to be anyone you want me ta  be.
Joyce smiles for the first time.
That's a dangerous offer. I'm a  notorious reformer...

A nervous JOYCE walks off the plane into the arrivals are She scans the crowd of friends, family, lovers and limo  drivers waiting to meet the disembarking passengers. Wher is Harvey? What will he look like? As Joyce surveys the unfamiliar faces, she imagines diffe versions of an animated, illustrated Harvey among the peo She double-takes as sees the R. CRUMB HARVEY -- hairy, sc smelly and picking his nose. Joyce rubs her eyes. Next she sees the BRANDO HARVEY (Gary Dumm), but unfortun he disappears fast. Disappointed, Joyce notices the realistic DREW FRIEDMAN H walking towards her. She smiles as he dissolves into:
Hey. Are you Joyce?
Joyce turns around. The flesh and blood HARVEY PEKAR stan before her -- not quite as bad as the Crumb version, not  quite as good as the Dumm version, but still acceptable. sighs with relief.
Hi, Harvey. We finally meet in person.
She politely offers her hand. Harvey shakes it, but he lo overwhelmed, worried and pessimistic.
Hiya. Look, before we get started  with any of this, ya might as well  know right off the bat. I had a  vasectomy.
Joyce lets go of his hand. She stares at him in disbelief

The most awkward date in history. Seated in an ultra-yupp restaurant filled with business lunchers, Harvey and Joyc hide behind their menus. While everyone else looks slick successful, these two compete for the world's worst postu
What's wrong?
Nothing.
Somethin's wrong. Yer lookin' around  everywhere.
I guess I never imagined you eating  in a place like this.
Me? I never been here. I thought  you'd like it. But obviously ya don't,  do ya?
It's fine. What difference does it  make?
Harvey shakes his head, feeling more pessimistic.
I dunno. None, I guess. (beat) They sure got a lot of meat on this  menu.
You're a vegetarian?
Kinda. I mean ever since I got a pet  cat, I couldn't eat animals anymore.
Joyce grabs a bread stick.

Hmm. I support and identify with  groups like PETA, but unfortunately  I'm a self-diagnosed anemic. Also, I  have all these food allergies to  vegetables that give me serious  intestinal distress. I guess I have  a lot of borderline health disorders  that limit me politically when it  comes to eating.
Harvey just stares at her.
Wow. Yer a sick woman, huh?
Not yet. But I expect to be. Everyone  in my family's got some kind of  degenerative illness.
A cheery waitress bounces over.
(sing song) Good afternoon! I'm your server Cindy!  What can I bring you two today?
They slowly look up at her.
JOYCE and HARVEY enter the apartment. The place is a mess as usual.

Look, I was gonna clean up, but why  should I give you any false notions?  The truth is I got a serious problem  with cleanliness. I could wash a  dish ten times and it'd still dirty.  They even kicked me outta the Army  'cause I couldn't learn ta make a  bed.
Joyce puts down her bag.
I've seen worse.
She slumps down on the sofa as if she's been here a milli times. She rubs her head. Harvey sits next to her.
Harvey, go get me water and a few  aspirin.
Harvey just bounces back up and obeys.
What, ya got a headache?
No, but I want to avoid one.
Harvey empties the aspirin bottle in his palm. For some  reason, he's feeling more comfortable.

Well lemme tell ya Joyce, it sure is  nice ta have company. I mean, despite  all your problems, you seem like a  great person. An' hey, sorry if my  dating skills are kinda rusty, but  I've just been through hell and back  with women. I mean that last one  turned out to be a real nasty bitch.
Harvey arrives back with the aspirin. He hands it to Joyc
I had a nice time with you, too.
Joyce swallows the pill. Harvey sits down next to her.
Yeah? You had a nice time?
Don't make people repeat themselves.  It's annoying.
Oh, sorry.
They're inches away from each other.
C'mere...
She pulls him close. Harvey plants a kiss on her. They slowly separate. Joyce's eyes are closed. She likes  him. He kisses her again. They start making out, moaning bit. But before it gets heavy --
Harvey?
Yeah?
Joyce opens her eyes. She looks uneasy.
Which door's the bathroom?
Harvey stands by the bathroom door, despondent. From insi we hear the sounds of moaning and flushing.
Hey, Joyce! What's wrong? What is  it?
FLUSH! Joyce is doubled over on the toilet. She's looking green.
Ugh! I don't know. I think that yuppie  food did me in.
I feel terrible. Lemme at least do  something for you.
Joyce gets to her feet and puts her glasses back on. She  picks up a can and sprays air freshener around the room. Then she looks at the can and realizes it's WD-40.
Can I make ya something? How about  some chamomile tea?
Joyce puts the can down.
Chamomile tea? What the hell's a guy  like you doing with that? I thought  you drink soda pop for breakfast.
I dunno. I noticed you drank a lot  of it when we started talkin' on the  phone. So I stocked up on herbal  teas for your visit.
Joyce turns her head to the door. She's truly surprised b what Harvey's just said. And very moved. She smiles to  herself.
Harvey stands there waiting.
The girl at the Food Co-op picked me  out all kinds of herbal stuff. One  of 'ems good for stomachaches. Grandma  Bear's Tummy Mint, I think. Are you  still there?
Joyce slowly opens the door. She leans against the door f like she's just been through a war. She takes off her glasses and cleans them off with her sh
Harvey, we better skip this whole  courtship thing and just get married.
Harvey and Joyce are in bed, lying in each other's arms. They look quite contented.
Man, am I glad I talked you into  comin' up here. Any more time alone  and I mighta lost it fer good.
Me too.
So you don't have any problems with  movin' to Cleveland?
Not really. I find most American  cities depressing in the same way.
An' yer okay with the vasectomy thing?
She shrugs.

HARVEY approaches the building. Instead of dragging his f like usual, he seems to be floating on a cloud. We haven' seen Harvey this happy since... well, since never. He stops by a junker car and peeks in the window, finding TOBY eating lunch alone. He has an entire White Castle  smorgasbord spread across the front seat. Harvey knocks on the window. Toby rolls it down.
Ay Toby.
(mouth full) No you can't have any of my White  Castle hamburgers so please don't  even ask.
Can I have a fry?
Harvey reaches for a handful of Toby's fries.
Okay, but just a couple, Harvey. I'm  not going to eat dinner until very  late and this has got to hold me  over.
Harvey leans in, always amused by Toby. He steals another fry.
(munching) Whattya got, a church function?
No, I'm driving to Toledo to see a  movie. Would you like to come?
Nah. I gotta fly to Delaware tonight.  I'm gettin' married.
Oh. Why Delaware?
The chick I'm marryin' is from  Wilmington. Plus, I gotta help her  move her stuff here. (a beat) Why you drivin' ta Toledo to see a  movie?
It's not playing at the Mapletown. (a beat) I didn't know you had a girlfriend,  Harvey.
Yeah. We met last week.
Harvey opens the car door and slides in with Toby.
Toby, what movie could possibly be  worth drivin' 260 miles round trip  for?

It's a new film called "Revenge of  the Nerds." It's about a group of  nerd college students who are being  picked on all the time by the jocks,  so they decide to take revenge. I  already saw it once.
Wow, ya really dig this movie.
I like it a lot, Harvey.
What are these nerds like? How would  you describe them?
Hmm... Nerds are smart but they look  and act differently than other people.  Like nerds might wear polyester button- down shirts and flood pants where  their ankles and their socks are  showing.
Toby spills some catsup on his polyester button-down shir He stands up to get a napkin, revealing his flood pants.
So what yer sayin' is you identify  with those nerds?

(rubbing out the catsup) Yes, I consider myself a nerd. And  this movie has uplifted me. There's  this one scene where a nerd grabs  the microphone during a pep rally  and announces that he is a nerd and  that he is proud of it and stands up  for the rights of other nerds. Then,  he asks the kids at the pep rally  who think they are nerds to come  forward... So nearly everyone in the  place does. That's the way the movie  ends.
So the nerds won, huh?
(smiling) Yes.
Harvey grabs the rest of Toby's fries and opens the door leave.
Wow. You got this movie an' I'm  gettin' hitched. We both had a good  month, huh?
(finishing his last  burger) Right. Harvey, how long are you going  to be in Delaware because I'd really  like to see this movie with you?
I'm only goin' for a week but then  I'll have a wife, so I'll have to  take her along. Is it a girl flick?
Depends on the girl. What kind of  girl is your new bride? Is she a  nerd?
I don't know, man. Maybe. She's into  herbal teas.
Toby watches Harvey saunter off. He returns to his last  hamburger.

A brightly lit marquee reads, "REVENGE OF THE NERDS." The doors to the theater open and a crowd pours onto the stre HARVEY, JOYCE and TOBY are among them. Toby proudly wears "Genuine Nerd" button on his striped shirt.
I agree with Toby. I think it's a  story of hope and tolerance.
Yes. It's about time that the people  who get picked on get to be the  heroes.
Harvey scrunches his face in disbelief.

It's an entertaining flick an' I can  see why you like it Toby, but those  people on the screen ain't even  supposed to be you! They're college  students whose parents live in big  houses in the suburbs. They're gonna  get degrees, get good jobs and stop  being nerds.
Joyce hits Harvey.
Harvey, what did I say about loud  talking? Use your inside voice.
(whispering loudly) Look Toby, the guys in that movie  are not 28-year-old file clerks who  live with their grandmothers in an  ethnic ghetto.
That's enough, Harvey.
They didn't get their computers like  you did -- by trading in a bunch of  box tops and $49.50 at the  supermarket.
Joyce folds her arms in disapproval. Toby starts to laugh
You're funny Harvey.
Harvey looks at him, disappointed. He shakes his head.
Sure, Toby. Go to the movies and  daydream, but "Revenge of the Nerds"  ain't reality. It's just Hollywood  bullshit.
Toby and Joyce continue to analyze the movie in the front seat as Toby starts the ignition.
Slouched, grumpy and alone on the back seat, Harvey's sti annoyed by the movie.
Okay, maybe I was bein' so harsh on  Toby onna count a' my own problems.

Y'see, I wasn't even married a month  and my old lady was already showin'  signs a' trouble. Granted, I tend ta  get married fast 'cause I'll take  any woman that'll have me, but this  time I really met my match...

A few items indicating film production are in the frame. At a table in the foreground, BOB THE DIRECTOR discusses character of Joyce with the ACTRESS playing her. The actr just nods as the director goes on. We can see THE REAL JOYCE sitting with THE REAL HARVEY in the distance.

Okay, I think the thing with Joyce  is that as manic as Harvey can be,  she matches him with depression. In  that way they complete each other. I  mean, she's obviously a very smart  woman, but she has a lot of trouble  functioning in a world she can't  control. And she's totally obsessed  with all things negative; y'know,  diseases, dysfuctions, etc.
THE REAL JOYCE and REAL HARVEY listen curiously -- someti pleased, sometimes displeased -- as their personalities a dissected and boiled down to a few phrases.

The REAL JOYCE puts in her two cents about the actress pl her. She rants about what it's like to be portrayed in a  movie, and having a character arc imposed on her life. She moves into talking about her relationship with Harvey and the first years of their marriage -- how impossible i was to live with him. The REAL HARVEY just rolls his eyes.

head_text.subj: END HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE

text: JOYCE is on a cleaning rampage. She rummages through pile upon piles of records while HARVEY paces nervously.
What about these 78's, Harvey? Can't  you sell them to one of those  collectors?
Are ya kidding? No way, man. I ain't  getting rid of my 78's.
Joyce throws down the records in frustration. Harvey runs over to check if they're scratched.
(angry) Forget it then. I give up! How can I  make more storage space, if you won't  get rid of anything?
I'll get rid of stuff. Just not my  good stuff.
Everything's your good stuff. How am  I supposed to live here, if there's  no room for me?
Aw come on, baby. I'll make room for  ya. You just have to give me time.  I'm not so good at these kind of  things.
That's because you're obsessive  compulsive Harvey.
A DOOR BUZZER rings. Harvey slams it to unlock the front.
C'mon. I don't wanna hear that  psychobabble crap!

I don't care if you wanna hear it or  not. You're the poster child for the  DSM III. I'll have you know that I  come from a very dysfunctional family.  I can spot personality disorders a  mile away...
A KNOCK ON THE DOOR interrupts their argument. Joyce stor away to answer it.
Joyce opens it to face a smiling TOBY -- dressed as usual a loud polyester fashion don't. He talks in his strange  robotic voice and avoids all eye contact.
Hello Joyce. Is Harvey home?
Joyce turns to Harvey and points to Toby.
Borderline autistic!
This scene shrinks into a square up in the corner. The ne few scenes (NEUROSIS MONTAGE) further divide up the full  screen like a comic book.
R. CRUMB leaps from behind an autograph table (where he's signing comics) to hop on the back of ZAFTIG BABE, who of him a piggy-back ride. Joyce turns to Harvey.
Polymorphously Perverse.
JOYCE picks up Harvey from work. HARVEY enters the car, w goodbye to the ranting MR. BOATS. She points to Mr. Boats.
Paranoid Personality Disorder.
THE TELEPHONE RINGS. A disheveled, tired-looking JOYCE fl through a novel and lets the machine pick up.
Please leave a message. (Beep)
(into phone) Hey Joyce, it's me. You're not gonna  believe this but some LA producer  called an' he wants to do a play  about my life. Call me! (Click)
Joyce flips the page.
(to herself) Delusions of grandeur.
END NEUROSIS MONTAGE (return to full screen)
HARVEY and JOYCE sit in a packed theater watching a play. Joyce looks exhausted.
A STAGE ACTOR HARVEY and a STAGE ACTOR JOYCE share a couc on the sparse stage.
See, I think comics can be an art  form. With pictures an' words, a guy  can do pretty much anything!
That's true, Harvey. But I didn't  come all the way from Delaware to  talk about comics ...
The "Stage Actor Joyce" lunges over and plants a kiss on  him.
Harvey digs it but Joyce looks disgusted.
We now see STAGE ACTOR HARVEY clutching a tea cup, as STA ACTOR JOYCE kneels before a toilet bowl. Off to the side the stage, A SPOT LIGHT illuminates a GUITAR PLAYER, who  adds music to the scene.
HARVEY and JOYCE walk through the terminal. Harvey brims  with energy but Joyce looks exhausted.

If ya think readin' comics about yer  life seems strange, try watchin' a  play about it. God only knows how  I'll feel when I see this movie. But  truth be told, the play wasn't half  bad, and we got a free trip outta  it. Things were goin' pretty good  for a change. Variety called me "The  Blue Collar Mark Twain," and Doubleday  was interested in publishing an  anthology of "American Splendor."
Harvey nervously taps his foot as he waits for the bags. Joyce leans against the carousel staring at a YOUNG MOTHE with a BABY in a Bjorn.
I hate checkin' bags, man. It always  takes forever.
He checks his watch. Joyce remains quiet and distant.
Jesus, look at the time. The bus is  gonna leave soon and there won't be  another one for an hour. That means  I gotta shell out an extra thirty  bucks for a cab.
Harvey spots a bag that he thinks is his.
Hey wait, there's our -- (a well-dressed man  grabs it) Figures. That lucky Yuppie's gonna  get on the bus in time.
Suddenly, Joyce mumbles something to Harvey.
Y'know Harvey, vasectomies are  reversible.
(ignoring her) Damn Yuppies get everything.
(raising her voice) Are you listening to me? I said  vasectomies are reversible.
Heads turn.
What? Whattya talkin' about? I don't  want kids. An' I came clean about my  vasectomy the first time I set eyes  on ya', right here in this airport.
More heads turn.
I know but things have changed. I  think we can be a family.
Family?! What kinda family could we  possibly be? I ain't no good with  kids. I can barely take care of  myself.
I'll take care of the kid and you.
(dead serious) No way Joyce. Forget it. I can't do  it; I can't have no kids.
Joyce folds her arms... dejected, defeated. The audience eavesdroppers looks disappointed as well.

If the place was a disaster before, believe it or not, it gotten worse. JOYCE seems to have given up on her  organizing... and everything else for that matter. HARVEY hysterically searches through the mess for a recor album. Joyce just lies listlessly on an open futon on the middle of the room; it looks as if she hasn't been up in  days.
Where the hell is that Ornette Coleman  album, Joyce? I got a review due  tomorrow.
Joyce rolls over.
I didn't touch it, Harvey. Would you  let me sleep?
But it's one o'clock! How late can a  person sleep?
Joyce sits up. This time she means business.

It happens to be Saturday you selfish  sonofabitch! And don't you go telling  me what to do. I'm the one who moved  into your city, into your home, into  your vasectomy and into your screwed- up life. The least you could do is  allow me to live here my way.
She rolls over and covers her head with the pillow. Harve just stands there staring at her.
I tried everything but nothin' could  get this woman outta bed.
HARVEY peruses the aisles. He pulls box upon box of herba tea off the shelves.
I mean she wouldn't get a job,  wouldn't go out, wouldn't make  friends, nothin'.
HARVEY throws boxes of herbal teas at JOYCE as she sprawl listlessly on the futon. She just yawns and turns over on her side.
Joyce diagnosed herself as "clinically  depressed." I don't know what the  hell she was goin' through but it  was sure takin' it's toll on me.
A frustrated Harvey tries once more to cheer her up.
(upbeat) We can go out for dinner tonight.  How 'bout catching a bite at Tommy's?
(mumbling) I'm not hungry.
Harvey throws his hands in the air and walks off.
I give up.
As he passes the answering machine, he notices it's blink
Hey Joyce, we got a message here.  Why didn't you pick up.
Joyce doesn't respond.
Useless.
He presses the play button. ANGLE ON ANSWERING MACHINE: A loud "beep," then ...

Hi, this is a message for Harvey  Pekar. My name is Jonathan Greene  and I'm a producer for LATE NIGHT  WITH DAVID LETTERMAN. We'd like to  talk to you about coming on the show  to plug your comics. Please give me  a call at 212-555-3333.
What the hell?
Joyce sits up. Harvey's finger hits the "Replay" button.
Hi, this is a message for Harvey --
The impressive skyline glistens in the spring sun.
Joyce finally got off the futon...

Armed with shopping bags from Bleecker Bob's Record Shop, the Strand Book Store and Forbidden Planet Comic Book  Emporium, HARVEY and JOYCE eat lunch on a park bench. Har chomps on a knish and watches oddball New Yorkers stroll as Joyce nibbles on her hot dog.
Cut back to reveal Harvey, schlepping an ice bucket down hall in his underwear. A FEMALE BUSINESS TRAVELER passes stares at him. He enters a room with a "DO NOT DISTURB" s

The PEKARS have already wreaked havoc on their luxury hot room. It looks like a tornado touched down on the New Yor Hilton. HARVEY tries on outfits for the big show. He pulls a wrin T-shirt over his head and models it for JOYCE who is spre out on the bed surrounded by piles of clothing, scissors sewing supplies. She glances up at Harvey's getup and sha her head no.
Aw, c'mon. Who the hell cares?
Harvey tosses his shirt over to Joyce, who snatches it an starts cutting it with a scissor.
Hey, whattya doin?
Merchandising.
She resumes her mysterious sewing project; she seems to b making some kind of doll.

Backstage, JOYCE watches LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN a monitor as HARVEY awaits his turn to go on camera. He h changed out of his wrinkled T-shirt into a slightly more  formal look -- a denim shirt and a ratty seersucker strip jacket.
A 1980's DAVID LETTERMAN wisecracks.
Neither Joyce nor Harvey look particularly impressed with the whole deal.
People like this show?
Harvey paces.
I'm gettin' hungry back here. They  oughtta leave ya donuts or somethin'.
A nervous STAGE MANAGER wearing a headset peeks his head
Dave's ready for you now, Mr. Pekar.
Hey, you got anything ta eat? My  stomach's growling.
(checking his watch) There's no time to eat now.
Harvey glances at the monitor just as Letterman announces his next guest.
Okay. Our next guest works as a file  clerk in a Cleveland hospital.
The stage manager grabs Harvey by the arm. Joyce stops th
Wait a minute. Where's the doll?
He's got it at the desk. Will you  relax about that already?
Guys, guys, we're in a hurry here.
The Stage Manager physically pushes Harvey out of the Gre Room. Joyce turns back to face the monitor.
Letterman holds up a copy of a full-size glossy AMERICAN  SPLENDOR ANTHOLOGY.

...He also writes comic books which  detail his day-to-day pains and  pleasures, and this is an anthology  of nine of those comics. It's entitled  AMERICAN SPLENDOR... From off the  streets of Cleveland, please say  hello to Harvey Pekar.

head_text.subj: THE HARVEY PEKAR WHO WALKS ONTO THE SET IS NOT THE ACTOR

text: PORTRAYING HIM BUT RATHER THE REAL HARVEY PEKAR (only abo 15 years younger). THIS IS ACTUAL STOCK FOOTAGE FROM HARV FIRST LETTERMAN APPEARANCE.
Joyce watches as Harvey shakes Letterman's hand and takes seat.
He smiles as the audience warmly greets him. It seems Har grooving on this attention. But as soon as the audience q down, Harvey turns to his host and starts his offensive:
I'm ready for those Cleveland jokes.  Go ahead...
Taken off guard, Letterman laughs.

Alright settle down Harvey. Settle  down. (the Audience laughs) Now let's explain to folks who may  not be familiar with your work what  it is you do here, exactly. You have  comic books about you in your daily  life in Cleveland.
That's right.
And are they embellished at all or  is it pretty much factual?
(patronizing) No. It's all true, David. All true.
And you also have a regular job in  Cleveland working at a hospital.
That's right. Aiding the sick, yes.
Aiding the sick. Well that's certainly  noble work.
Thank you. Thank you.
(unimpressed) Such brilliant repartee...
Now it seems to me Harvey that you  have a very successful career here.  This is being published by a major  publishing company, Doubleday. Why  do you maintain the day job?
(defensive) To make a living! (big laughs) I don't make a living as a writer.  I've been writing for many years,  David. Maybe more years than you've  been alive.
Now, Letterman cracks up.
A LETTERMAN REGULAR (Tony Randall?) comes in with some fo He stops by the monitor to watch a moment with Joyce.
Yeah, I know that my youthful  appearance belies, you know, my actual  age. But, I've been around for a  long time --
(to JOYCE) You know this guy?
I'm beginning to wonder.
The Letterman Regular takes a seat as he watches the moni He seems more intrigued than Joyce.

But I have a feeling though, if you  wanted to, you could probably get by  on what you make selling your work.  Because I know people are after you  to write other things. You're  publishing this anthology...
This hits a sore spot. Harvey goes from politely condesce to cantankerous in one second flat!
Who? What people? What people? What  are you talking about? Where the  hell do you get that stuff?
Letterman cracks up. The Audience laughs even harder.
I'm no show biz phoney. I'm telling  the truth. Come on, man.
The Audience can't believe this guy's holding his own wit Letterman.
(to Joyce) At least he's keeping up with  Letterman.
Pandering is more like it.
Suddenly, Joyce walks over to the monitor and looks for t channel. She hits a button, but it only changes the frame the show.
Damnit.
Excuse me, but what are you doing?
I'm trying to get some news. You  know there's a big story about to  break about the US selling arms to  Iran and the Contras.
That's a monitor.
Ugh. Just forget it.
Joyce gives up. She sinks back into her seat and pulls a  book from her bag. The Letterman Regular stares at her li she's from Mars.
Harvey, I know you've got a job.  I've got a job. We're both very lucky.  We both have jobs.
Then what's the matter?
Once again laughs and a big round of applause. Letterman  pulls out Joyce's mysterious doll and props it up on the  table.
We've gotta go. Harvey I like you.  I'm on your side. I enjoy the comic  books. And here, quickly tell us  about the little doll here.
My wife made it.
She suddenly perks up.
Finally something good. (to Letterman Regular) Watch this.

It is an absolutely horrific but oddly evocative "Harvey Doll." His face is inspired by Crumb's drawings of Harvey but even more extreme. His little T-shirt reads, "America Splendor." The Audience is in stitches.
They're made out of your old clothing.
That's right.
And what do these go for?
Thirty-four bucks.
(shocked) Thirty-four dollars? Thirty-four  dollars for this?
What are ya cheap. You cheaper than  me?
Would you pay thirty-four dollars  for that?
No but I'm not asking it. My wife  is.
JOYCE stares at the monitor, expressionless. The STAGE MA sticks his head in.
He's a natural.
He is. Good stuff.
The Stage Manager grabs the Regular.
C'mon. Your turn.
A smiling HARVEY (the actor now) waltzes in straight from his command performance.
Whad'ya think?
Joyce taps her finger on Letterman's image on the monitor
Megalomaniac.
HARVEY tries on a ripped T-shirt for Joyce who lies on th bed.

It became clear pretty fast that I  was invited on the show just for  laughs. But what the hell did I care?  Letterman was an okay guy. Let him  take pot shots at me, s'long as I  got paid an' got to plug my comics.
MONTAGE: A series of actual HARVEY appearances on LATE NI WITH LETTERMAN.
JOYCE, whose different outfits reflect time passage, watc each time from the GREEN ROOM. LETTERMAN SHOW - STOCK FOO HARVEY, in a ratty T-shirt, spars with LETTERMAN.
Harvey, you are the embodiment of  the American dream...
The Audience laughs.
Funny thing is, somethin' about me  and Letterman clicked for the viewers.  He kept wantin' me back.
LETTERMAN introduces his favorite guest.
It is my pleasure to welcome back  our next guest, the lovable Harvey  Pekar!
HARVEY walks out with a box of donuts. He starts giving  Letterman an earful right off the bat.
Here was this slick, ambitious guy  with millions, winnin' over the  country by makin' light of everything.  And then there was me... A messy  loser with no dough who takes  everything too seriously.
Tell me Harvey, what do you do to  get away from the pressure of being --  well, a file clerk? (laughter)
Go ahead and laugh, folks. But he  has more contempt for you than I do!
The burger joint has been transformed into a film set wit lights, cameras and lots of trendy MTV types.
An it wasn't just me gettin' all the  attention. As a result of my  appearances on Letterman, my buddy  Toby Radloff landed a gig on MTV  extolling the virtues of White Castle  burgers...

Two HOT BABES slave over TOBY as he gets his hair and mak up done. HARVEY wanders onto the set. He finally spots Toby in the corner. As he heads over to say hello, Harvey bumps into MTV DIRECTOR -- a new wave fashion victim who looks like lost member of A FLOCK OF SEAGULLS.
Christ! Watch where you're going!
(muttering) Fuckin' yuppie or whatever kinda  freak you are.

That day on the set with those MTV  jerks, I had an epiphany. It seemed  that real, salt of the earth people  like Toby an' me were bein' coopted  by these huge corporations. We were  gettin' held up and ridiculed as  losers in the system.  What can I  say, it was the 80's man.
TOBY, dressed in dark sunglasses and a turtleneck, stands front of a White Castle. He delivers his lines in his  trademark robotic style. There's an MTV logo on the botto of the screen.
Hamburgers are a safer addiction  than drugs. Say no to drugs. Say yes  to White Castle!
HARVEY and JOYCE eat breakfast together. Harvey reads a  Katherine Mansfield book as JOYCE reads a newspaper.
(looking up from the  paper) Harvey, I've been reading about these  kids who grew up in war zones...  Palestinians, Israelis, El  Salvadorians, Cambodians... These  kids are amazing and they're --
A YUPPIE in a jogging suit walks up to Harvey, interrupti Joyce in mid-sentence.
Hey, you're that guy from the  Letterman show, right?
(smiling) Yeah, that's me.
That's so excellent. You and Stupid  Pet Tricks are a riot.
Harvey's not smiling anymore. This guy's a jerk.
Yeah? Then why dontcha buy one of my  comics, man. That's the only reason  I go on that dumb show anyway.
Right, sure. Later, Harvey Pekar!
The Yuppie rushes out.
Asshole.
Anyway, I want to do a political  comic book about these kids. There's  a conference in Jerusalem in a few  weeks, and I can start by doing  interviews there.
Whoa whoa, wait a second. Jerusalem?  I can barely drag you off the futon  to go to the Letterman show.
Y'know why? 'Cause I don't give a  damn about the Letterman show. I  want to work on something important  to me. Something that matters.
Joyce hits a nerve.
(furious) Hey! You know I only go on the show  for the extra bread!
People start to look over.
Harvey... you're yelling...
Maybe if you got yer lazy ass up and  got a job, I could work on something  that matters, too, huh?!
Joyce doesn't dignify Harvey with an answer. She stares a him, her eyes well with hurt. He sighs, calming down. He looks around sheepishly.
I'm sorry, baby. I -- I'm sorry...
He grabs her hand.
Harvey and Joyce stroll across the lawn holding hands. Th move towards a waiting cab. Harvey carries his wife's bag
I guess it was good ta finally see  Joyce excited about somethin' of her  own. Sure I was happy for her. But I  was still upset for me.
They stop by the cab.
This is crazy. Can't ya just do  somethin' here in Cleveland?
Harvey, you'll survive a few weeks  alone.
Alright... Be careful. I love you,  baby.
They kiss. Harvey grudgingly puts her bags in the car. He watches as the cab pulls away.
It was later that night when I first  found the lump.

Wearing only his shorts, Harvey lies alone in the communa futon, flipping through a book. He reaches into his under to scratch his nuts. Suddenly he stops. He feels something odd... For a moment he just freezes. His eyes register panic.
I was determined to put it outta my  mind until Joyce got back. Easier  said than done.
An enraged HARVEY fights with his co-worker MIGUEL.
What do I care! Just gimme the chart  already!
What is your problem today?!
Look, Miguel! I just don't wanna  keep comin' back here for it, okay?!
Harvey, that patient's due t'be  admitted a week from now! Why do you  always have to be picking fights  with everybody?
(yelling) How many times do we gotta go through  the same bullshit. Just gimme the  fuckin' chart!
Offended, Miguel storms off.
We'll see what the doctor says about  this.

Alone and slumped over his table, HARVEY draws comic idea with stick figures. Nothing's coming to him. He looks lik he's in anguish. Frustrated, Harvey crumbles the idea and throws it on the floor. He knocks over a chair.
He tosses and turns in bed. No way he's sleeping.
HARVEY is yelling into the telephone. It is a bad connect
(loudly into phone) Whadya mean? Another two weeks? Ya  gotta come home some time! Hello?  DAMNIT!
Without Joyce, a surly Harvey waits in the wings for his  introduction. He sneaks a peek as Letterman finishes up t "stupid pet tricks" segment. We hear dogs barking and aud laughter.
And there you have it, folks! Another  enlightening episode of Stupid Pet  Tricks!

I was startin' ta lose it. Between  the lump, the loneliness -- I felt  like everything wuz closin' in on  me. And with Joyce over there savin'  the world, I never felt more like a  sell-out hack in my life.
Y'know ladies and gentlemen, when  Thoreau wrote that most men lead  lives of quiet depression, he  obviously had not met our first guest,  who happens to lead a life of whining  desperation...
Harvey clenches his fists.
(threatening) Okay, asshole. You'll pay for that  one...
Harvey takes off his shirt. He pulls another t-shirt out the bag and changes ...
Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome  back, Harvey Pekar.
Harvey's new t-shirt reads "ON STRIKE AGAINST NBC." He ta off for the stage, fists clenched, a soldier marching off war.
We're positioned behind the monitor, so we can only hear show. THE STAGE MANAGER AND TWO PRODUCTION ASSISTANTS  straighten up in the room.
Hey, Dave! You wanna know what my  politics are? I'm a strident leftist,  Dave.
I could have guessed half of that.
You coulda guessed all of it, man!  So why don't we talk about your parent  company, G.E., huh? Let's talk about  anti-trust violations and nuclear  reactors!
Joe, put more sodas in the fridge,  there. And let's clean up the  counters. That Pekar guy's a pig.
As the P.A.'s walk back and forth in front of the monitor we hear the Letterman / Pekar banter grow louder. Suddenly PRODUCTION ASSISTANT #2 stops and checks out the monitor.
Whoa... you guys. Check this out.
TOBY and his GRANDMOTHER watch HARVEY raise hell on Lette Again, we can't see the screen.
You're a cop-out, Letterman. You're  nothin' but a shill for G.E.
Toby's grandmother passes him a plate of cookies.

First of all, Harvey, what you are  saying is not true. Second of all,  this is not the place to say it. If  you want to talk about this, go  somewhere else, because you're not  talking about it here!!
Dressed in a bathrobe, Mr. Boats eats a lonely, late-nigh snack (cake and milk) at his kitchen table. A 12" TV on t table has Harvey and Dave on.
Don't worry, Dave. I won't come back  unless you beg me.
You're not coming back at all.
What do I care --
Because we've given you many, many  chances to talk about things that  would be of general interest to people --
So what?!
Mr. Boats shakes his head.
We see Harvey alone, slumped in the back seat of a Town C heading back towards his hotel. City lights pass over his troubled face. We still hear the show, as if it's now in head.
-- And also to promote your little  Mickey Mouse magazine. Your little  weekly reader! But you've blown every  chance you've got. You're a dork,  Harvey!
Dave, you're fulla shit! You're fulla  shit!!
