The cover depicts a snarling LETTERMAN yelling, "YOU FUCK UP A GREAT THING!" at a smirking, self-satisfied HARVEY. JOYCE lies in bed reading the comic, chuckling. HARVEY cu up against her.
I guess you did it this time.
Who cares. He wasn't helpin' my sales  anyway. (moving closer) Baby, don't go away anymore. I just  can't take bein' alone.
Joyce puts the magazine down.
If you met those kids over there and  saw what they go through, you wouldn't  ask that of me.
But if you go again I'm really gonna  lose it.
It's not open for discussion, Harvey.  I need this in my life right now.
She cuddles up close to him.
But I do appreciate the fact that  you missed me so much. C'mere...
She starts to kiss him. He kisses her back. Her hands wan down. Suddenly she feels something strange.
Harvey, what is that?
Harvey looks at her and gulps.
HARVEY and JOYCE sit in the office holding hands, like tw terrified high school kids. A DOCTOR stands before them. They just got bad news...
I don't understand, does "tumor"  mean the same thing as "cancer"?

The doctor gently nods. Joyce covers her mouth. Harvey holds onto his head. He lo positively dizzy. The doctor starts to talk, yet the word don't seem to match his mouth. He looks dubbed. Strange  phrases just weave together, echo and bounce off the wall making no sense at all. ...we know the growth is malignant. What we don't know is how far it may have spread. Once we have the results of t biopsy, we can make more informed decisions about treatme blah, blah, blah... The whole office seems to spin.
Joyce and Harvey sit on the stoop of their apartment hous in a daze. The words keep echoing around them. Harvey hol his head.
...cat scan... diagnosis... MRI...  cancer... cancer... cancer...
How can I have cancer? I don't feel  sick at all.
That's a positive thing.
My cousin Norman died of lymphoma.  He was twenty-nine. He was a brilliant  oncologist.
Stop it! You're not going to die,  Harvey. You're not.
Harvey turns to Joyce.
What's going to happen to you, baby?  Who's gonna take care of you if I'm  not around?
Joyce stands up, determined.
Harvey, look at me and focus. We are  going to get through this. I  understand illness. I know how to  handle these things.
But that's you. I'm not strong enough.  I don't know how ta be positive. I  can't do it. I can't.

Yes, you can. And I'll tell you how.  You'll make a comic book out of the  whole thing. You'll document every  little detail. And that way you'll  remove yourself from the experience  until it's over.
Despite Joyce's passionate pitch, Harvey shakes his head.
I can't do that. I'm just not strong  enough... I just wanna die.
Joyce folds her arm.
Fine. I'll do it without you.
HARVEY and JOYCE lay there quietly, both exhausted. Joyce turns over so her back faces Harvey. He puts his arm arou her.
A tear drips down her cheek.
Joyce is straightening up the apartment. The place actual looks halfway decent.
Joyce opens the door. A guy in his 30's named FRED -- Hel Angels tough guy meets sensitive artist -- stands at the  door. He's accompanied by a seven-year-old girl, DANIELLE
Hey, I'm Fred. You called me about  the comic book?
Right -- the artist. Come on in.
This is my daughter, Danielle. I had  to bring her along. I hope you don't  mind.
Joyce leans down and addresses the girl, who holds a toy  horse.
Hi, Danielle. What's that you're  holding?
A pony.
It's immediately obvious that Joyce is great with kids.
A pony? What's his name?
She's a girl. Clarissa.
Oh, I see. Well, I'm Joyce. Nice to  meet both you and Clarissa.
They all walk towards the table which is covered with pap
I'm really sorry to hear about Harvey.  Is he here?
He's going to work until next week,  when he starts the chemo. That's why  I wanna get this project started  now. Once he's stuck here, I know  he'll take over.
Miserable and in a daze, HARVEY walks up to his front doo He looks like a man whose days are numbered. When he reac the door, he searches his pockets for keys.
Harvey's hand comes up empty.
Shit!

1960 was the year I got my first  apartment and my first telephone  book. Imagine my surprise when I  looked up my name and saw that, in  addition to me, another Harvey Pekar  was listed!
Images of Harvey's childhood float by, followed by his yo adult years.
I was listed as Harvey L. Pekar...  My middle name is Lawrence... He was  listed as Harvey Pekar -- no middle  initial... Therefore, his was a purer  listing.
We see Harvey age in the images: he's hanging on the stre corner with friends, collecting records, hanging with Cru
Then, in the seventies, I noticed  that a third Harvey Pekar was listed  in the phone book! This filled me  with curiosity.
How could there be three people with  such an unusual name in the world,  let alone in one city?!
Now, numerous images of Harvey's many years at the V.A.  Hospital float by: Harvey filing, Harvey arguing with his boss, Harvey and Toby, etc.

Then one day, a person I worked with  expressed her sympathy to me  concerning what she thought was the  death of my father. She pointed out  an obituary notice in the newspaper  for a man named Harvey Pekar. One of  his sons was named Harvey. These  were the other Harvey Pekars.
The comic images fade out. Harvey is once again alone in empty room.

Six months later, Harvey Pekar Jr.  died. Although I'd met neither man,  I was filled with sadness. "What  were they like," I thought. It seemed  that our lives had been linked in  some indefinable way.
We slowly move in on his face. Extremely close. As close the camera can get.
But the story does not end there.  For two years later another Harvey  Pekar appeared in the directory.  What kind of people are these? Where  do they come from, what do they do?  What's in a name?

Here's our man a year later. Somehow  I made it through the treatments,  an' the doctors are optimistic. I  guess Joyce was right about doin'  the big comic book. The weirdest thing that came outta  my illness was Danielle. Yeah, so I guess comics brought me a  lot. But don't think this is some  sunny, happy ending. Every day is  still a major struggle. Joyce an' I  fight like crazy, an' she barely  works. The kid's got A.D.D. and is a  real handful. My expenses have gone  up so much that I'm writin' freelance  'round the clock, just to make my  bills. My life is total chaos.

With a little luck, I'll get a window  of good health between retirin' an  dyin'. The golden years, right? Who  knows.
